headline: Bruce Degen, Who Drew ‘The Magic School Bus,’ Dies at 79
abstract: He memorably portrayed a frizzy-haired science teacher roping her elementary school class into adventures aboard a shape-shifting yellow bus.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Degen, the illustrator of “The Magic School Bus” series of children’s books, which gained a reputation as the clearest and most charming science texts available for elementary school students and have been read by tens of millions of children worldwide, died on Thursday at his home in Newtown, Conn. He was 79.
snippet: He memorably portrayed a frizzy-haired science teacher roping her elementary school class into adventures aboard a shape-shifting yellow bus.

headline: Man Arrested in Shooting That Killed One at Tuskegee University
abstract: The shooting, which also wounded 12 people, happened early on Sunday as crowds gathered at the historically Black school to celebrate the final day of its 100th homecoming week.
lead_paragraph: A 25-year-old man was charged in connection with a shooting on the campus of Tuskegee University in Alabama early Sunday morning that left one person dead and a dozen others wounded as crowds gathered for the school’s homecoming celebration, the authorities said.
snippet: The shooting, which also wounded 12 people, happened early on Sunday as crowds gathered at the historically Black school to celebrate the final day of its 100th homecoming week.

headline: Chaos, Provocations and Violence: How Attacks on Israeli Soccer Fans Unfolded
abstract: Antisemitic assaults on visiting Israeli soccer fans, and incendiary chants and attacks by some Israelis: Here’s what we know so far about the violence in Amsterdam last week.
lead_paragraph: Early Thursday morning, taxi drivers gathered en masse outside Amsterdam’s Holland Casino. Hours before, Israeli soccer fans had stolen and burned a Palestinian flag, while others attacked a cab — and the drivers, the police said, were heeding an online call to “mobilize.”
snippet: Antisemitic assaults on visiting Israeli soccer fans, and incendiary chants and attacks by some Israelis: Here’s what we know so far about the violence in Amsterdam last week.

headline: This Is the Cake We Baked
abstract: Talking to people who helped make Donald Trump’s victory happen, and others.
lead_paragraph: On This Week’s Episode:
snippet: Talking to people who helped make Donald Trump’s victory happen, and others.

headline: Military Judge Postpones Guilty Plea Proceedings in Sept. 11 Case
abstract: The judge asked defense and prosecution lawyers to settle on a date for the accused mastermind of the terrorist attacks to plead guilty.
lead_paragraph: A military judge on Sunday postponed a hearing to receive the guilty plea of Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, who is accused of masterminding the Sept. 11 attacks, so that prosecutors can seek again to nullify the plea deal.
snippet: The judge asked defense and prosecution lawyers to settle on a date for the accused mastermind of the terrorist attacks to plead guilty.

headline: No Corrections: Nov. 11, 2024
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Nov. 11, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
snippet: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Nov. 11, 2024.

headline: Trump’s Return Hangs Over U.N. Climate Negotiations
abstract: The election of Donald J. Trump is sapping momentum from global climate talks as diplomats brace for his pro-fossil-fuel agenda.
lead_paragraph: World leaders gathering in Baku, the capital of Azerbaijan, on Monday for a global climate summit face a bleak reality: The United States, the country responsible for pumping the most greenhouse gases into the atmosphere, is expected to soon drop out of the fight against climate change.
snippet: The election of Donald J. Trump is sapping momentum from global climate talks as diplomats brace for his pro-fossil-fuel agenda.

headline: Why Is a Petrostate Holding This Year’s Climate Talks?
abstract: The economy of Azerbaijan, host of COP29, relies almost entirely on the fossil fuels that are the main driver of global warming.
lead_paragraph: Heading into this month’s United Nations-sponsored climate negotiations, the world is contending with rising climate chaos and declining democracy.
snippet: The economy of Azerbaijan, host of COP29, relies almost entirely on the fossil fuels that are the main driver of global warming.

headline: Quote of the Day: These A.I. Glasses Tell All at a Glance, and Bring Up Thorny Issues
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, November 11, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “This is the kind of technology that could be incredibly useful and incredibly destructive.”
snippet: Quotation of the Day for Monday, November 11, 2024.

headline: Will Trump Rekindle a Bromance With Kim Jong-un? South Koreans Worry.
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s second term brings uncertainty to the Korean Peninsula as nuclear tensions run high. North Korea’s leader may see a chance to re-engage.
lead_paragraph: During his 2024 election campaign, Donald J. Trump described the United States’ alliance with South Korea as a terrible bargain for his country, accusing the Asian ally of not paying enough ​for the 28,500 ​American troops ​stationed on its soil.
snippet: Donald J. Trump’s second term brings uncertainty to the Korean Peninsula as nuclear tensions run high. North Korea’s leader may see a chance to re-engage.

headline: Monday Briefing
abstract: What Trump means for the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: As president, Donald Trump was a staunch supporter of Israel, recognizing Jerusalem as its capital, cutting off aid to the U.N. agency that supports Palestinian refugees and presenting a peace plan that favored Israel. Yet he has also publicly called for the war in Gaza to stop, saying in April, “Israel has to be very careful, because you’re losing a lot of the world.”
snippet: What Trump means for the Middle East.

headline: Why Did Tens of Thousands of Chinese Students Go on Night Bike Rides?
abstract: Making the impromptu five-hour ride between two Chinese cities became a craze among young people. But as their numbers swelled, the authorities shut it down.
lead_paragraph: The students would emerge on their bikes, in the tens of thousands, seemingly out of nowhere. Like a flash mob on wheels, they rode for hours in the night, by the light of streetlamps, sometimes bursting into verses of the Chinese national anthem. Some carried Chinese flags.
snippet: Making the impromptu five-hour ride between two Chinese cities became a craze among young people. But as their numbers swelled, the authorities shut it down.

headline: The Quiet Development Shaking America’s Power
abstract: The United States can no longer depend on the loyalty of its friends.
lead_paragraph: With the stunning comeback of Donald Trump as president, America’s allies are scrambling. Behind their sober messages of congratulation is a palpable anxiety that Washington will soon treat them as mere pawns on the global chessboard. It would be quite a change. Under President Biden’s leadership, the United States — sharpening its rivalry with China and seeking to counter Russia’s invasion of Ukraine — put great store in strengthening its alliances and partnerships.
snippet: The United States can no longer depend on the loyalty of its friends.

headline: ‘Dune: Prophecy,’ Plus 6 Things to Watch on TV this Week
abstract: Tune into the premiere of the HBO series, see whom Joan Vassos picks for her final rose on “The Bachelorette” and catch up on news.
lead_paragraph: Between streaming and cable, there is a seemingly endless variety of things to watch. Here is a selection of TV shows and specials that are available to watch live or stream this week, Nov. 11-17. Details and times are subject to change.
snippet: Tune into the premiere of the HBO series, see whom Joan Vassos picks for her final rose on “The Bachelorette” and catch up on news.

headline: Trump Names Thomas Homan ‘Border Czar’ With a Wide Portfolio
abstract: Mr. Homan, a senior immigration official in the last Trump administration, has said that workplace raids would restart under the new government.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump said late Sunday that he had named Thomas D. Homan, a senior immigration official in his last administration, as the “border czar” in charge of the nation’s borders and its maritime and aviation security.
snippet: Mr. Homan, a senior immigration official in the last Trump administration, has said that workplace raids would restart under the new government.

headline: Mattel Mistakenly Lists Porn Site on Packaging for ‘Wicked’ Dolls
abstract: The site has a similar address to one that promotes a film adaptation of the hit musical. The toymaker apologized for the “unfortunate error.”
lead_paragraph: All may be good in the Land of Oz, but the same can’t be said for the world of Mattel.
snippet: The site has a similar address to one that promotes a film adaptation of the hit musical. The toymaker apologized for the “unfortunate error.”

headline: He’s Eric Adams’s Third N.Y.P.D. Boss. Does He Have Staying Power?
abstract: Thomas Donlon wants the job of police commissioner permanently, and he’s been acting as though he has it as he navigates friction and uncertainty.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Eric Adams’s decision to appoint Thomas Donlon, a 71-year-old former F.B.I. investigator, as New York’s interim police commissioner seemed to bring a sense of stability to a department rocked by several federal inquiries. It didn’t last long.
snippet: Thomas Donlon wants the job of police commissioner permanently, and he’s been acting as though he has it as he navigates friction and uncertainty.

headline: Trump’s Gains Among Latinos Push a Civil Rights Group to Reflect on Its Past
abstract: From its founding nearly a century ago, LULAC encouraged Hispanic people to embrace American identity even as it fought discrimination. The 2024 election result presents a dilemma on both fronts.
lead_paragraph: On a cold and rainy Sunday in February 1929, a group of Latino men in dapper suits and boater hats gathered in a convention hall in Corpus Christi, Texas, to forge a new Latino civil rights group.
snippet: From its founding nearly a century ago, LULAC encouraged Hispanic people to embrace American identity even as it fought discrimination. The 2024 election result presents a dilemma on both fronts.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
snippet: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.

headline: How Trump Divides Chinese Who Aspire to Democracy
abstract: A new HBO documentary about opposition to autocrats says a lot about the complex politics the president-elect inspires for people fleeing countries.
lead_paragraph: The long and loud campaign of Donald J. Trump, and now his re-election as president, have prompted deep divisions among many Chinese who advocate for democracy.
snippet: A new HBO documentary about opposition to autocrats says a lot about the complex politics the president-elect inspires for people fleeing countries.

headline: After Trump’s Victory, Mayoral Candidates Unite Against Adams and Cuomo
abstract: Unseating Eric Adams as mayor of New York was a hot topic at a political gathering in Puerto Rico, as Democrats reflected on the impact of Donald J. Trump’s win.
lead_paragraph: At beachfront hotel bars, tropical pool parties and crowded ballroom dance floors, a pressing matter closer to home inevitably arose: How would New York City navigate four years of Donald J. Trump as president, and who might be the best mayor to lead that effort?
snippet: Unseating Eric Adams as mayor of New York was a hot topic at a political gathering in Puerto Rico, as Democrats reflected on the impact of Donald J. Trump’s win.

headline: Who Has the Best View of the Chrysler Building? These Bees.
abstract: On and around some of New York City’s most iconic buildings, beehives are buzzing.
lead_paragraph: At many corporate offices in Manhattan, the level of activity remains well below its prepandemic levels. But on and around some of New York City’s most iconic buildings, beehives are buzzing seven days a week.
snippet: On and around some of New York City’s most iconic buildings, beehives are buzzing.

headline: Shigeru Ishiba Wins Vote to Remain as Japan’s Prime Minister
abstract: Parliament voted Monday to stick with Mr. Ishiba, who will lead a minority government after his party suffered heavy losses in an election last month.
lead_paragraph: Despite leading his party to big losses in a snap general election last month, Shigeru Ishiba, the prime minister of Japan, won a vote in Parliament on Monday to carry on as the country’s leader.
snippet: Parliament voted Monday to stick with Mr. Ishiba, who will lead a minority government after his party suffered heavy losses in an election last month.

headline: Throngs of Cyclists Ride for Hours Between Two Chinese Cities
abstract: They were making the 40-mile journey from Zhengzhou, the capital of Henan Province, to the neighboring city of Kaifeng, a cycling trip that can take up to five hours one-way.
lead_paragraph: They were making the 40-mile journey from Zhengzhou, the capital of Henan Province, to the neighboring city of Kaifeng, a cycling trip that can take up to five hours one-way.
snippet: They were making the 40-mile journey from Zhengzhou, the capital of Henan Province, to the neighboring city of Kaifeng, a cycling trip that can take up to five hours one-way.

headline: Women Get Less Exercise Than Men. It’s a Problem.
abstract: Experts say the fitness gender gap is because women have less time to work out, and that their health is paying the price.
lead_paragraph: After a full Saturday shuttling her two kids to soccer and play-dates across Manhattan, Neha Ruch, 39, finally carved out a few precious minutes to exercise at 6:15 p.m. She didn’t even bother to change clothes before hopping onto her elliptical machine in a closet-turned-home-gym.
snippet: Experts say the fitness gender gap is because women have less time to work out, and that their health is paying the price.

headline: The Unspoken Grief of Never Becoming a Grandparent
abstract: A growing number of Americans are choosing not to have children. Their parents are grappling with what that means for them.
lead_paragraph: Lydia Birk, 56, has held on to her favorite copy of “The Velveteen Rabbit” since her three children — now in their 20s and 30s — were young.
snippet: A growing number of Americans are choosing not to have children. Their parents are grappling with what that means for them.

headline: Why Are Cities Still Spending Big on Convention Centers?
abstract: Cities are spending more than ever to land the biggest events, but companies have long pulled back on spending for annual conferences and attendance has dwindled.
lead_paragraph: Are sprawling convention centers worth the money cities need to spend on them?
snippet: Cities are spending more than ever to land the biggest events, but companies have long pulled back on spending for annual conferences and attendance has dwindled.

headline: Fewer Crowds, Bargain Prices: ‘Quiet Season’ Cruising in the Mediterranean
abstract: Overtourism and summer heat have increased the allure of off-season travel in Europe, and the cruise industry is taking note with more winter itineraries. Added bonus: cheaper fares.
lead_paragraph: After a summer of overtourism in cruise ports like Barcelona and Amsterdam, and talk of caps on ship arrivals in Greece and other places, the cruise industry has come up with a surprising suggestion for where to sail in winter: Europe.
snippet: Overtourism and summer heat have increased the allure of off-season travel in Europe, and the cruise industry is taking note with more winter itineraries. Added bonus: cheaper fares.

headline: I Gave My Son the Books I Loved. He Chose ‘Heidi’ Instead.
abstract: What a 19th-century Swiss novel, and a young fan’s pilgrimage to the Alps, taught me about fatherhood.
lead_paragraph: I went to the Alps in August because my son — a New York City third grader obsessed with baseball, projectiles and YouTube — fell in love this summer with the Swiss children’s novel “Heidi.”
snippet: What a 19th-century Swiss novel, and a young fan’s pilgrimage to the Alps, taught me about fatherhood.

headline: Alcohol Brands Tap the Art World to Woo Younger Drinkers
abstract: Will labels and bottles designed by artists gin up enthusiasm among an increasingly abstinent generation?
lead_paragraph: In October, Dom Pérignon hosted a party at the Brant Foundation in New York City’s East Village, thousands of miles from its home in the Champagne region of France. At the party, which celebrated Dom Pérignon’s partnership with the estate of Jean-Michel Basquiat, the actresses Zoë Kravitz and Natasha Lyonne, the model Evan Mock and Raul Lopez, the designer of the subversive Luar fashion label, sipped Dom as they swayed to music from the Mudd Club habitué DJ Justin Strauss.
snippet: Will labels and bottles designed by artists gin up enthusiasm among an increasingly abstinent generation?

headline: Allison Tolman Knows Her Worth
abstract: The actress broke out in “Fargo” and has spent the decade since convincing producers she is a leading lady. Now she’s starring in “St. Denis Medical,” a new hospital mockumentary.
lead_paragraph: “Hello, baby,” the actress Allison Tolman said to a handsome male. “Look at your mustache.” He crawled into her lap.
snippet: The actress broke out in “Fargo” and has spent the decade since convincing producers she is a leading lady. Now she’s starring in “St. Denis Medical,” a new hospital mockumentary.

headline: 5 Vintage Crime Novels Spiked With Peril and Pitfalls
abstract: Our columnist on a handful of recently reissued crime novels, all of which are worth your time.
lead_paragraph: Most of my recent conversations about books have revolved around one common pursuit: escape. The news is unrelenting, and crises personal and political abound. No wonder so many people are seeking out books that are either completely untethered to current reality or soothe us in the gentlest, coziest ways.
snippet: Our columnist on a handful of recently reissued crime novels, all of which are worth your time.

headline: How a Colombian Influencer Made Recycling Cool
abstract: The character Marce the Recycler has created an enthusiastic dedication to proper waste separation among her devoted fans.
lead_paragraph: In an enormous warehouse filled floor to ceiling with plastic, glass and newspapers, Sara Samaniego lip-syncs to a rap song, dressed in her trademark blue jumpsuit and braids.
snippet: The character Marce the Recycler has created an enthusiastic dedication to proper waste separation among her devoted fans.

headline: Jewelry With the Seafaring Spirit of ‘Treasure Island’
abstract: Van Cleef & Arpels’s latest collection draws from Robert Louis Stevenson’s classic adventure novel.
lead_paragraph: In 1906, the Belgian lapidary and diamond dealer Alfred Van Cleef and his brother-in-law Salomon Arpels opened a jewelry boutique on the ground floor of the Hôtel de Ségur, an 18th-century private mansion in Paris’s First Arrondissement that had once belonged to a prominent winemaker. That same year, the pair produced one of their first custom orders: a scale model of the then-ultramodern Varuna of New York yacht that featured a yellow-gold double-masted deck and hull set in green, alabaster and crimson enamel on a sea of solid jasper. Meant to ornament a tabletop, it initially had an electric butler’s bell inside its funnel. Over the following decades, the house’s decorative objects and jewelry would return to their maritime iconography: a 1935 minaudière was adorned with a three-pronged platinum-and-diamond-encrusted clasp resembling a trio of overlapping sails billowing in the wind; pendant charms from the mid-20th century depicted nautical scenes with bejeweled sloops and lapis lazuli waves.
snippet: Van Cleef & Arpels’s latest collection draws from Robert Louis Stevenson’s classic adventure novel.

headline: The New Era of West African Fine Dining
abstract: Across the diaspora, chefs are sharing knowledge about long-overlooked cuisines — and creating some of the most exciting dishes you’ll find in Europe and America today.
lead_paragraph: IN THE MINIMALIST dining room of MoSuke, a restaurant on Paris’s Left Bank, a black sauce fills the hollow of a white plate. The ingredient necessary to achieve this depth of color comes from a tree that grows nearly 3,000 miles away in the rainforests of Cameroon: Afrostyrax lepidophyllus, whose every part — trunk, leaves, the round brown seeds called country onions — gives off the scent of garlic, most strongly after rain. The Bassa people, who live in the nation’s south, cut the bark into strips, then burn, crush and press it through a sieve until it’s fine as gunpowder.
snippet: Across the diaspora, chefs are sharing knowledge about long-overlooked cuisines — and creating some of the most exciting dishes you’ll find in Europe and America today.

headline: How ‘The Wild Robot’ Was Born in a Weedy Patch of Manhattan
abstract: Peter Brown’s obsession with the abandoned railway that became the High Line led to two best sellers — including “The Wild Robot,” which is now a blockbuster movie.
lead_paragraph: Peter Brown was in Manhattan’s meatpacking district in 2002 when he noticed a few hardy branches dangling from a dingy overpass near Gansevoort Street.
snippet: Peter Brown’s obsession with the abandoned railway that became the High Line led to two best sellers — including “The Wild Robot,” which is now a blockbuster movie.

headline: 7 Shows That Make This Art Festival Worth the Trip to California
abstract: The sprawling PST festival of more than 70 exhibitions doesn’t quite live up to its theme of art and science colliding. But there is a handful of impressive entries.
lead_paragraph: Bigger and bulkier than ever, the art omnibus formerly called “Pacific Standard Time,” now known by the snappier “PST,” is making its once-every-several-years appearance across Southern California this fall. Bankrolled by the Getty Foundation and centered in Los Angeles, the $20.4 million initiative is made up of more than 70 exhibitions, organized by museums and nonprofit spaces large and small, and gathered, with varying degrees of cogency, under a single thematic banner: “PST ART: Art & Science Collide.”
snippet: The sprawling PST festival of more than 70 exhibitions doesn’t quite live up to its theme of art and science colliding. But there is a handful of impressive entries.

headline: The Jazz-Metal Trio PainKiller’s Classic Lineup Revs Up Again
abstract: Mick Harris, Bill Laswell and John Zorn’s new album, “Samsara” — their first in 30 years — arrives as Laswell battles health troubles that “opened up a new direction.”
lead_paragraph: In the spring of 1991, John Zorn, the radically eclectic composer and saxophonist, hopped into a cab outside his East Village apartment. Already inside was Mick Harris, a young drummer visiting from Britain whose band, Napalm Death, had become the leading exemplar of grindcore, a caustic, velocity-crazed blend of punk and metal. Their destination: Greenpoint Studios, the Brooklyn headquarters of the prolific bassist-producer Bill Laswell, Zorn’s friend and collaborator.
snippet: Mick Harris, Bill Laswell and John Zorn’s new album, “Samsara” — their first in 30 years — arrives as Laswell battles health troubles that “opened up a new direction.”

headline: Everyone Else Is Giving a Standing Ovation. Do I Have To?
abstract: Theatergoers and other performing-arts lovers are noticing the practice seems to have become the rule, not the exception.
lead_paragraph: Do you have a question for our culture writers and editors? Ask us here.
snippet: Theatergoers and other performing-arts lovers are noticing the practice seems to have become the rule, not the exception.

headline: To Understand Egypt, Meet My Friend, a Political Prisoner
abstract: When we were younger, my friend Alaa Abd El Fattah and I didn’t know just how intimately prison, and state violence, would shape our lives.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after I arrived at Tora Maximum Security Prison in Cairo, a prisoner with a trendy haircut and glasses entered my cell, handed me a plastic bag and whispered, “From Alaa.” Inside the bag were several packs of cigarettes, the currency of the prison; blue and white T-shirts, the only colors prisoners could wear; and small plastic packets of tea and sugar.
snippet: When we were younger, my friend Alaa Abd El Fattah and I didn’t know just how intimately prison, and state violence, would shape our lives.

headline: How the Tale of a Brutal Shipwreck Became a Broadway Musical
abstract: The Avett Brothers were all ears a decade ago when a determined crew of theater upstarts and veterans came aboard to adapt their maritime album for “Swept Away.”
lead_paragraph: In the early days of the 21st century, before the Top 5 albums and the three Grammy nominations, the Avett Brothers were a band of three young guys, relentlessly touring their blend of folk-rock-country, sprinting from show to show in their van. Between gigs, Scott Avett’s father gave him a copy of “The Custom of the Sea,” Neil Hanson’s book chronicling the 19th-century wreck of the Mignonette, a British yacht, and its tragic aftermath.
snippet: The Avett Brothers were all ears a decade ago when a determined crew of theater upstarts and veterans came aboard to adapt their maritime album for “Swept Away.”

headline: Caught Between Wars, Syrian Refugees in Lebanon Return Home
abstract: Hundreds of thousands of Syrians who escaped civil war at home over the past decade have now fled the conflict in Lebanon, seeking safety in their own shattered country.
lead_paragraph: When the civil war in Syria threatened his village more than a decade ago, a farmer and his family fled to neighboring Lebanon.
snippet: Hundreds of thousands of Syrians who escaped civil war at home over the past decade have now fled the conflict in Lebanon, seeking safety in their own shattered country.

headline: Mortgage Rates Fell, Then Rose. What Comes Next?
abstract: Many would-be home buyers are still hoping for mortgage rates to come down as the Federal Reserve cuts interest rates. How much they will fall is unclear.
lead_paragraph: Rafael Corrales, a real estate agent in Miami, recently showed houses to a young couple hoping to move from a rental into a home. They had been lured to the market after hearing that mortgage rates had come down.
snippet: Many would-be home buyers are still hoping for mortgage rates to come down as the Federal Reserve cuts interest rates. How much they will fall is unclear.

headline: He Dressed America. Now He Wants to Dress You.
abstract: Aaron Levine has designed for Abercrombie & Fitch, Club Monaco and Madewell. This week, he’s introducing a brand of his own.
lead_paragraph: Aaron Levine had a pretty good idea he was going to be fired from Abercrombie & Fitch.
snippet: Aaron Levine has designed for Abercrombie & Fitch, Club Monaco and Madewell. This week, he’s introducing a brand of his own.

headline: The Booker Prize Is Tuesday. Which of These 6 Novels Should Win?
abstract: Percival Everett’s “James” is the favorite for the prestigious literary award. But the likes of Rachel Kushner’s “Creation Lake” or Samantha Harvey’s “Orbital” could take the prize instead.
lead_paragraph: A tale of erotic obsession that gradually becomes a story about the Holocaust. A novel set aboard a space station. A book set in a convent that experiences a plague of mice.
snippet: Percival Everett’s “James” is the favorite for the prestigious literary award. But the likes of Rachel Kushner’s “Creation Lake” or Samantha Harvey’s “Orbital” could take the prize instead.

headline: How Do You Spell Rock Royalty? R.E.M.
abstract: In a new biography, Peter Ames Carlin chronicles the rise of an indispensable band and the evolution of its music.
lead_paragraph: It takes a village to raise a rock band. That’s part of the premise of Peter Ames Carlin’s sensitive and well-made new biography, “The Name of This Band Is R.E.M.” The village was Athens, Ga., in the late 1970s and early ’80s, where an art and music scene thrived in the shadow of University of Georgia football.
snippet: In a new biography, Peter Ames Carlin chronicles the rise of an indispensable band and the evolution of its music.

headline: Army Private Is Identified Almost 80 Years After Death in World War II
abstract: Jeremiah P. Mahoney had been missing in action since 1945. His remains will be interred in Arlington National Cemetery in 2025.
lead_paragraph: Seven months after the pivotal D-Day invasion of the French coast, a baby-faced Army private from Chicago and his anti-tank company were resupplying and reinforcing Allied forces for weeks along a 40-mile-wide front on the France-Germany border in early January 1945.
snippet: Jeremiah P. Mahoney had been missing in action since 1945. His remains will be interred in Arlington National Cemetery in 2025.

headline: As Trump Threatens a Wider Trade War, the U.S. Confronts a Changed China
abstract: The Chinese economy is more dependent on exports, making tariffs more potent, yet it’s less reliant on American markets and increasingly bent on self-sufficiency.
lead_paragraph: Eight years ago, when a newly elected Donald J. Trump promised to apply the powers of the Oval Office to start a trade war with China, the target of his ire was widely viewed as a juggernaut. China was the indispensable factory floor to the world and a swiftly developing market for goods and services.
snippet: The Chinese economy is more dependent on exports, making tariffs more potent, yet it’s less reliant on American markets and increasingly bent on self-sufficiency.

headline: Do You Know What It Takes to Close on a New Home? Take Our Quiz.
abstract: The final step of a real estate purchase can be the most complicated.
lead_paragraph: The final step of a real estate purchase can be the most complicated.
snippet: The final step of a real estate purchase can be the most complicated.

headline: The Trump Era Never Really Ended
abstract: Should we even call it a comeback?
lead_paragraph: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. How are you feeling — despondent, energized, enraged, dumbstruck?
snippet: Should we even call it a comeback?

headline: Democrats Could Have Won. Our Excuses Mask a Devastating Reality.
abstract: Many young voters didn’t perceive the tangible impact of their 2020 support for Joe Biden, which eroded their faith in the Democratic Party.
lead_paragraph: Inflation was too high. Turnout was too low. President Biden stayed in the race too long. His summer polling deficit was too steep to overcome.
snippet: Many young voters didn’t perceive the tangible impact of their 2020 support for Joe Biden, which eroded their faith in the Democratic Party.

headline: What’s the Best Thing to Wear on a First Date?
abstract: A reader wonders if received wisdom about a certain “ideal outfit” still holds true. Our fashion critic offers a first-date fashion philosophy.
lead_paragraph: First of all, there is no such thing as a single ideal outfit. People, of all ages, shapes, geographies and situations, are too gloriously varied. What I can offer, however, is a first-date fashion philosophy.
snippet: A reader wonders if received wisdom about a certain “ideal outfit” still holds true. Our fashion critic offers a first-date fashion philosophy.

headline: $865,000 Homes in California
abstract: A Queen Anne Revival-style house in Oakland, a manufactured home from 1962 in Newport Beach, and a one-bedroom condo in the Hollywood Hills.
lead_paragraph: This three-bedroom, three-bath house is in North Oakland, less than a mile from the waterfront shopping centers of Emeryville and less than two miles from the south side of Berkeley, Calif. A public library, a cocktail bar and an Ethiopian restaurant are all within a half mile, as is Temescal Creek Park. An outpost of the Berkeley Bowl market is five minutes away by car, and the campus of the University of California, Berkeley is 15 minutes away.
snippet: A Queen Anne Revival-style house in Oakland, a manufactured home from 1962 in Newport Beach, and a one-bedroom condo in the Hollywood Hills.

headline: Trump and Musk: The Bromance That Cannot Last
abstract: Now that he has been elected, Donald Trump will probably not honor the promises he made to Elon Musk.
lead_paragraph: So sorry, Elon Musk, but the bromance is not going to last. I know the president-elect put you on the phone with President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine the night after the election. And I know that in Donald Trump’s victory speech, after obligatory but abbreviated nods to his “beautiful wife,” his “amazing children” and his “feisty” vice president-elect, he celebrated your super-genius as only he could, in a disjointed, discombobulated, wildly overextended paean and declaration of love. “Oh, let me tell you, we have a new star,” he said. “A star is born, Elon.”
snippet: Now that he has been elected, Donald Trump will probably not honor the promises he made to Elon Musk.

headline: Against Panic: A Survival Kit
abstract: There is no cure for profound grief, but beauty and love and tenderness can walk alongside it and ease the solitude.
lead_paragraph: I had an elaborate itinerary for Election Day that I took to calling the Panic Abatement Plan. I’d walk in the woods early because temperatures are still breaking records down here. I’d stop by Parnassus Books, which would be full of kindred souls, and pick up my special order, Rachel Carson’s “The Sense of Wonder.” I’d visit the puppy room at the Nashville Humane Association. I’d have lunch with one friend, and I’d talk on the porch with another. I’d take my new book out to the yard and read while sugar maple leaves fell in golden drifts around me in the last light of day.
snippet: There is no cure for profound grief, but beauty and love and tenderness can walk alongside it and ease the solitude.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,242
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Nov. 12, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
snippet: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Nov. 12, 2024.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 520
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, Nov. 12, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
snippet: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, Nov. 12, 2024.

headline: Trump Transition Stalls Over Ethics Code, and a New Russian Offensive
abstract: Plus, Saudi Arabia’s “sportswashing” controversy.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:
snippet: Plus, Saudi Arabia’s “sportswashing” controversy.

headline: Democrats Search for Answers
abstract: After their election loss, the party’s leaders are pointing fingers and wrestling with what it stands for.
lead_paragraph: Democrats, devastated by their sweeping losses in the election, are starting to sift through the wreckage of their defeat.
snippet: After their election loss, the party’s leaders are pointing fingers and wrestling with what it stands for.

headline: Democrats Who Won
abstract: We’re covering this year’s successful Democratic campaigns.
lead_paragraph: In a very bad year for their party, some Democrats still figured out how to win tough races.
snippet: We’re covering this year’s successful Democratic campaigns.

headline: Israel’s Military Announces Small Expansion of Gaza Humanitarian Zone
abstract: The move comes just before a Biden administration deadline for Israel to deliver more aid to the enclave or risk a cutoff of military supplies.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s military said on Monday that it had expanded a humanitarian zone it created in southern Gaza. The move came just before the expiration of a Biden administration deadline for Israel to deliver more aid to the enclave or risk a cutoff of military supplies.
snippet: The move comes just before a Biden administration deadline for Israel to deliver more aid to the enclave or risk a cutoff of military supplies.

headline: A Potential Fight Over the Fed’s Future Ramps Up
abstract: As Trump allies including Elon Musk endorse ending the Federal Reserve’s independence, the central bank’s chair is reportedly ready to go to court to fight back.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s threat to exert more say over the Fed or even fire Jay Powell, the chair of the central bank, has alarmed some on Wall Street. But the president-elect’s effort took on added weight in recent days, after Elon Musk endorsed a push to erode the Fed’s independence.
snippet: As Trump allies including Elon Musk endorse ending the Federal Reserve’s independence, the central bank’s chair is reportedly ready to go to court to fight back.

headline: Trump Offers Elise Stefanik Role as U.N. Ambassador
abstract: In one of his first cabinet-level personnel decisions, the president-elect has chosen the Republican member of Congress from New York to represent the United States at the United Nations.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump has offered Representative Elise Stefanik, Republican of New York, the role of U.N. ambassador in his upcoming administration.
snippet: In one of his first cabinet-level personnel decisions, the president-elect has chosen the Republican member of Congress from New York to represent the United States at the United Nations.

headline: Iran and Trump Are Front of Mind at Saudi Summit
abstract: Leaders from across the Arab and Muslim world were in Riyadh for a meeting officially convened to discuss the fighting in Gaza and Lebanon.
lead_paragraph: Leaders from across the Arab world gathered on Monday in the capital of Saudi Arabia for a summit that came at a delicate moment for the kingdom, which has signaled a rapprochement with Iran after a violent, decades-long rivalry.
snippet: Leaders from across the Arab and Muslim world were in Riyadh for a meeting officially convened to discuss the fighting in Gaza and Lebanon.

headline: Iran Debates Whether It Could Make a Deal With Trump
abstract: Some in Iran’s new, more moderate government think the result of the presidential election provides an opportunity to make a lasting deal with the United States.
lead_paragraph: President Donald J. Trump pulled out of the 2015 nuclear pact between Iran and world powers, imposed tough economic sanctions on Iran and ordered the killing of its top general. And Iran, federal prosecutors said on Friday, plotted to assassinate Mr. Trump before November’s election.
snippet: Some in Iran’s new, more moderate government think the result of the presidential election provides an opportunity to make a lasting deal with the United States.

headline: Bitcoin and Stocks Set Records as Bullish Bets Continue
abstract: The cryptocurrency hit $88,000 and the Dow Jones industrial average reached a new high as a rally that began after Donald J. Trump’s election continued to gain steam.
lead_paragraph: Bitcoin passed $88,000 for the first time and major stock indexes set records on Monday, as markets continued to rally following Donald J. Trump’s victory in last week’s election.
snippet: The cryptocurrency hit $88,000 and the Dow Jones industrial average reached a new high as a rally that began after Donald J. Trump’s election continued to gain steam.

headline: Israel Issues New Evacuation Warnings in Lebanon
abstract: The widespread orders across southern Lebanon came amid what appeared to be intensifying efforts to reach a cease-fire.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military issued new evacuation warnings for more than 20 towns and villages in southern Lebanon on Monday, and Hezbollah unleashed a large rocket barrage into northern Israel, the latest indications that the conflict showed few signs of abating.
snippet: The widespread orders across southern Lebanon came amid what appeared to be intensifying efforts to reach a cease-fire.

headline: Jamie Oliver Pulls Children’s Book Amid Criticism of Insensitivity
abstract: The celebrity chef’s second children’s book, “Billy and the Epic Escape,” faced accusations that it stereotyped First Nations people in Australia.
lead_paragraph: The British celebrity chef Jamie Oliver has halted sales of his children’s book around the world and issued an apology in response to accusations that the book stereotyped Australian Indigenous culture.
snippet: The celebrity chef’s second children’s book, “Billy and the Epic Escape,” faced accusations that it stereotyped First Nations people in Australia.

headline: The Singular Force That Was Judith Jamison
abstract: She was always a goddess of dance — even before her triumph in “Cry.” The Ailey star turned artistic director stretched like there was no tomorrow.
lead_paragraph: The ovation lasted for almost 10 minutes. The solo that prompted it was only six minutes longer.
snippet: She was always a goddess of dance — even before her triumph in “Cry.” The Ailey star turned artistic director stretched like there was no tomorrow.

headline: Why Trump’s Deportations Will Drive Up Your Grocery Bill
abstract: How will voters react?
lead_paragraph: For the past few years, over and over, voters have told pollsters and pundits that they’re hopping mad about inflation. Well, we just elected a president who, if he follows through on two of his central campaign promises — across-the-board tariffs and mass deportation of undocumented immigrants — will probably cause soaring inflation.
snippet: How will voters react?

headline: How to Dye Your Own Hair and Not Regret It
abstract: At-home tips from a model, an artist and a professional colorist.
lead_paragraph: “Don’t do it” is the most common advice you tend to hear about coloring your own hair. But despite all the horror stories of breakage and brassy streaks, many people embrace the challenge; once you’ve mastered the process, it’s hard to argue with the convenience and creative control. For advice, we talked to three self-taught experts: Soo Joo Park, a Los Angeles-based model known for regularly changing the color of her salon-bleached hair; Aliyah’s Interlude, an Atlanta-born music artist and TikTok star who has tried a multitude of shades on her natural hair and wigs; and Josh Wood, a British colorist whose entry into the business was dying his own hair as a teenager. The key, they say, is to know your limits and allow yourself some grace for mistakes.
snippet: At-home tips from a model, an artist and a professional colorist.

headline: Uranus Might Have Experienced a Freak Event When Voyager 2 Visited
abstract: Much of the understanding of the seventh planet comes from a brief flyby nearly 40 years ago, which researchers now say overlapped with an exceptional solar event.
lead_paragraph: Our understanding of Uranus might have been all wrong for nearly 40 years.
snippet: Much of the understanding of the seventh planet comes from a brief flyby nearly 40 years ago, which researchers now say overlapped with an exceptional solar event.

headline: Healing the Political Divide and Despair
abstract: Readers discuss the rancor and mistrust and suggest ways to come together. Also: Floods in America; support for youths; the arbitration illusion.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
snippet: Readers discuss the rancor and mistrust and suggest ways to come together. Also: Floods in America; support for youths; the arbitration illusion.

headline: Hama Amadou, West African Political ‘Phoenix,’ Dies at 74
abstract: An embattled leader for decades in Niger’s rough-and-tumble politics, he alternated stints in high office with prison and exile.
lead_paragraph: Hama Amadou, a West African politician who alternated stints in high office in Niger with prison and exile, a reflection of his country’s turbulent politics, died on Oct. 24 in Niamey, the capital. He was 74.
snippet: An embattled leader for decades in Niger’s rough-and-tumble politics, he alternated stints in high office with prison and exile.

headline: Zhuzh Up This Risotto However You Like
abstract: Or don’t: A bowl of classic, creamy risotto is perfect on its own.
lead_paragraph: Today seems to me like a good day to stir the pot — the risotto pot, I mean. Traditional recipes have you add broth bit by bit as you stir constantly, and even though you really need to stir it only now and then (so the rice doesn’t stick to the bottom of the pan), a session of rhythmic, gentle stirring can be just what you need at the end of a long day.
snippet: Or don’t: A bowl of classic, creamy risotto is perfect on its own.

headline: The Trump Insiders Who Have Outsize Influence as He Chooses His Cabinet
abstract: Aides like Susie Wiles and advisers like Elon Musk are weighing in as the president-elect shapes his new administration.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump has been known to cast a wide net when seeking advice for hiring decisions. As his team ramps up the presidential transition process, Mr. Trump is calling friends and associates for input on who should be part of his administration, which he says will radically reshape the federal government.
snippet: Aides like Susie Wiles and advisers like Elon Musk are weighing in as the president-elect shapes his new administration.

headline: Paul Mescal Rides ‘A Streetcar Named Desire’ to Brooklyn
abstract: The award-winning production will begin performances in February as part of Brooklyn Academy of Music’s next season.
lead_paragraph: Brooklyn Academy of Music next spring will present an Olivier Award-winning revival of “A Streetcar Named Desire” starring Paul Mescal, the Irish actor, in the role made famous by Marlon Brando.
snippet: The award-winning production will begin performances in February as part of Brooklyn Academy of Music’s next season.

headline: Trump Transition Signals Focus on Deportations as Miller Assumes Influence
abstract: President-elect Donald Trump is expected to name the immigration hard-liner Stephen Miller as deputy chief of staff and announced a former ICE official as his “border czar.”
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump is signaling with his staffing decisions his intention to carry out a campaign promise of widespread deportations of undocumented immigrants and tightening of measures that allow some of them to stay in the country legally.
snippet: President-elect Donald Trump is expected to name the immigration hard-liner Stephen Miller as deputy chief of staff and announced a former ICE official as his “border czar.”

headline: Netanyahu Seeks to Delay Testifying at His Corruption Trial
abstract: Benjamin Netanyahu, the Israeli prime minister, is on trial for bribery and fraud. Now he wants to delay giving testimony.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has requested to delay testifying at his ongoing corruption trial, fueling criticism that he is seeking to drag out the case in order to delay a verdict and, if convicted, a jail term.
snippet: Benjamin Netanyahu, the Israeli prime minister, is on trial for bribery and fraud. Now he wants to delay giving testimony.

headline: Lou Donaldson, Soulful Master of the Alto Saxophone, Dies at 98
abstract: A player of impeccable technique and a mainstay of the Blue Note label, he recorded constantly as both a leader and a sideman beginning in 1952.
lead_paragraph: Lou Donaldson, an alto saxophonist who became part of the bedrock of the jazz scene and whose soulful, blues-steeped presence in the music endured undiminished for three-quarters of a century, died on Saturday. He was 98.
snippet: A player of impeccable technique and a mainstay of the Blue Note label, he recorded constantly as both a leader and a sideman beginning in 1952.

headline: What to Know About Elise Stefanik, Trump’s Pick for U.N. Ambassador
abstract: Ms. Stefanik, who chairs the House Republican Conference, undertook a dramatic transformation that brought her to the center of Donald J. Trump’s orbit.
lead_paragraph: Representative Elise Stefanik of New York has been one of President-elect Donald J. Trump’s most ferocious allies for years, defending him during his two impeachments, amplifying his lies about the 2020 election and rallying behind his comeback campaign.
snippet: Ms. Stefanik, who chairs the House Republican Conference, undertook a dramatic transformation that brought her to the center of Donald J. Trump’s orbit.

headline: Review: A Superficial Take on Migration as Movement
abstract: At the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the highlight of Dana Gingras’s “Frontera” may well be the lighting design.
lead_paragraph: Migration is among the most consequential of global forces. As a subject manifest in the movement of bodies, it seems especially suited for dance to address, and that is what “Frontera,” a work by the Canadian choreographer Dana Gingras, promises.
snippet: At the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the highlight of Dana Gingras’s “Frontera” may well be the lighting design.

headline: California Counts Methodically as House Control Hangs in the Balance
abstract: Nine of the 16 races that will determine which party controls the House of Representatives are in California. No state takes longer to tally votes.
lead_paragraph: The nation is again waiting on California to finish tallying votes almost a week after Election Day.
snippet: Nine of the 16 races that will determine which party controls the House of Representatives are in California. No state takes longer to tally votes.

headline: Why Was There a Broad Drop-Off in Democratic Turnout in 2024?
abstract: Many Democrats failed to turn out to vote at the rate they did in 2020 when they ousted Donald Trump, according to an analysis of election data.
lead_paragraph: Voters in liberal strongholds across the country, from city centers to suburban stretches, failed to show up to vote for Vice President Kamala Harris at the levels they had for Joseph R. Biden Jr. four years earlier, contributing significantly to her defeat by Donald J. Trump, according to a New York Times analysis of preliminary election data.
snippet: Many Democrats failed to turn out to vote at the rate they did in 2020 when they ousted Donald Trump, according to an analysis of election data.

headline: Spirit Airlines Plane Hit by Gunfire in Haiti and Forced to Divert
abstract: A day after the prime minister of Haiti was fired, the airport in Port-au-Prince was closed because of the attack on the aircraft. A JetBlue plane was also struck.
lead_paragraph: A Spirit Airlines flight attempting to land in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, was shot at on Monday and forced to divert, marking a sharp escalation in the violence that has gripped the nation.
snippet: A day after the prime minister of Haiti was fired, the airport in Port-au-Prince was closed because of the attack on the aircraft. A JetBlue plane was also struck.

headline: Why Do So Many Americans Pass Up Bigger Social Security Checks?
abstract: It shouldn’t be so easy to leave benefits on the table.
lead_paragraph: People get just 70 percent of their full Social Security benefit if they claim at 62, the full benefit at 67 and 124 percent of the benefit if they claim at 70. The gain from waiting is so big that it pays for most people to keep working,or even to dip deep into their retirement savings early to cover their expenses so they can delay claiming.
snippet: It shouldn’t be so easy to leave benefits on the table.

headline: Bishop Calls on Anglican Leader to Quit Over Handling of Abuse Scandal
abstract: An independent report last week said that the Most Rev. Justin Welby, the archbishop of Canterbury, took insufficient action after learning of alleged abuse decades ago at Christian summer camps.
lead_paragraph: A Church of England bishop on Monday called for the resignation of the archbishop of Canterbury, the Most Rev. Justin Welby, days after a report concluded that he had failed to ensure a proper investigation into claims of sadistic abuse decades ago at Christian summer camps.
snippet: An independent report last week said that the Most Rev. Justin Welby, the archbishop of Canterbury, took insufficient action after learning of alleged abuse decades ago at Christian summer camps.

headline: Indiana Man Convicted of Killing 2 Girls After Video Found on Victim’s Phone
abstract: A jury on Monday found Richard Allen guilty of killing Liberty German and Abigail Williams, who were on a hike in 2017. Video showed a man following the girls.
lead_paragraph: An Indiana man was found guilty on Monday of killing two girls on a wooded trail in 2017 in a case that garnered national attention, spawned podcasts and riveted true-crime fans drawn to the case’s twists and turns.
snippet: A jury on Monday found Richard Allen guilty of killing Liberty German and Abigail Williams, who were on a hike in 2017. Video showed a man following the girls.

headline: Biden Honors Veterans in Ceremony at Arlington Cemetery
abstract: “This is the last time I will stand here at Arlington as commander in chief,” President Biden said in remembering service members who have served the country.
lead_paragraph: President Biden urged Americans to take a moment to honor those who serve in the military and their families on Monday, using the backdrop of Arlington National Cemetery to observe Veterans Day one last time as the country’s commander in chief.
snippet: “This is the last time I will stand here at Arlington as commander in chief,” President Biden said in remembering service members who have served the country.

headline: Former Staten Island Representative Is Paralyzed After Fall From Horse
abstract: Michael Grimm, a Republican who resigned in 2015 after pleading guilty to felony tax evasion, was paralyzed from the chest down during a polo competition in September.
lead_paragraph: Michael Grimm, a former U.S. representative from Staten Island, was paralyzed after a fall from a horse during a polo competition in September. The condition of Mr. Grimm, a Republican and former F.B.I. agent and Marine who resigned from Congress in 2015 and served seven months in prison for tax fraud, was first reported by a colleague from Newsmax, where Mr. Grimm had found a second career as an on-air personality.
snippet: Michael Grimm, a Republican who resigned in 2015 after pleading guilty to felony tax evasion, was paralyzed from the chest down during a polo competition in September.

headline: Tuesday Briefing: Trump Starts Building His Cabinet
abstract: Plus, West African fine dining.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald Trump is making decisions about his administration.
snippet: Plus, West African fine dining.

headline: Trump Chooses Lee Zeldin to Run E.P.A. as He Plans to Gut Climate Rules
abstract: The former congressman from New York is a strong supporter of Donald Trump and voted against certifying the 2020 election.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump announced on Monday that he would nominate former Representative Lee Zeldin, Republican of New York, to lead the Environmental Protection Agency, a position that is expected to be central to Mr. Trump’s plans to dismantle landmark climate regulations.
snippet: The former congressman from New York is a strong supporter of Donald Trump and voted against certifying the 2020 election.

headline: Trump Plans Series of Executive Orders for Day 1, Susie Wiles Tells Donors
abstract: Ms. Wiles, the next White House chief of staff, said Donald Trump would move quickly to reinstate orders from his first term that President Biden had revoked, though she did not specify which ones.
lead_paragraph: Susie Wiles, the next White House chief of staff, privately told a group of Republican donors on Monday that President-elect Donald J. Trump would move on his first day in office to reinstate several executive orders from Mr. Trump’s first term that President Biden had revoked, according to two people in the room who insisted on anonymity to describe the closed-door remarks.
snippet: Ms. Wiles, the next White House chief of staff, said Donald Trump would move quickly to reinstate orders from his first term that President Biden had revoked, though she did not specify which ones.

headline: As the Pandemic Deepened, Americans Kept Drinking More
abstract: Excessive drinking persisted in the years after Covid arrived, according to new data.
lead_paragraph: Americans started drinking more as the Covid-19 pandemic got underway. They were stressed, isolated, uncertain — the world as they had known it had changed overnight.
snippet: Excessive drinking persisted in the years after Covid arrived, according to new data.

headline: New York Times Tech Guild Ends Strike
abstract: The union said its members would return to work on Tuesday, even though it had not yet reached a contract deal with the company.
lead_paragraph: The Times Tech Guild, which represents more than 600 tech workers at The New York Times, announced on Monday that it had ended its weeklong strike despite not reaching a deal on a contract.
snippet: The union said its members would return to work on Tuesday, even though it had not yet reached a contract deal with the company.

headline: Amsterdam Police Arrest 5 More Men Over Antisemitic Attacks
abstract: A total of eight people were being held in connection with last week’s violence, and unrest in the largest city in the Netherlands continued on Monday night.
lead_paragraph: The police in Amsterdam arrested five more people on assault charges this weekend, four of whom are still being held, over the attacks on Israeli soccer fans in the city late last week after a match between an Israeli and a Dutch team.
snippet: A total of eight people were being held in connection with last week’s violence, and unrest in the largest city in the Netherlands continued on Monday night.

headline: Murder Suspect Who Alleged Bear Attack Is Captured in South Carolina
abstract: The suspect was taken into custody, ending a multistate manhunt in a case involving a suspicious emergency call, a false identity and a fake bear attack.
lead_paragraph: Law enforcement officials have captured a man who was wanted for murder in rural Tennessee, ending a multistate manhunt in a bizarre case involving a suspicious emergency call, a false identity and a fake bear attack.
snippet: The suspect was taken into custody, ending a multistate manhunt in a case involving a suspicious emergency call, a false identity and a fake bear attack.

headline: Democrats Pick Up Seat in Newly Drawn Louisiana District
abstract: Cleo Fields, a longtime Baton Rouge politician, won more than 50 percent of the vote in an open primary, negating the need for a runoff.
lead_paragraph: Democrats have picked up a seat with victory in Louisiana’s newly drawn Sixth Congressional District, according to The Associated Press.
snippet: Cleo Fields, a longtime Baton Rouge politician, won more than 50 percent of the vote in an open primary, negating the need for a runoff.

headline: Remembering Quincy Jones, a Bridge Between Genres and Generations
abstract: A conversation about his long and unique footprint in music, and how he discussed it later in his career.
lead_paragraph: Early this month, Quincy Jones, one of the most influential and creative forces in American pop music history, died at 91. The scope of his success almost defies comprehension — his work began in the 1950s and continued all the way up through recent years. He produced the most important Michael Jackson albums, and also Frank Sinatra, and also “We Are the World.” He won 28 Grammys. Sarah Vaughan, Miles Davis, Usher, the Weeknd, Lionel Hampton, “The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air,”: He crossed paths with all of them, and more.
snippet: A conversation about his long and unique footprint in music, and how he discussed it later in his career.

headline: I.C.C. Prosecutor Seeking Arrest of Israeli Leaders Faces Own Inquiry
abstract: The International Criminal Court said there will be an investigation into sexual misconduct allegations against Karim Khan, the court’s chief prosecutor.
lead_paragraph: The International Criminal Court will commission an independent investigation into accusations of sexual misconduct by its chief prosecutor, the court announced Monday.
snippet: The International Criminal Court said there will be an investigation into sexual misconduct allegations against Karim Khan, the court’s chief prosecutor.
